boat.construction_details: Long keel, with 6 tonnes of lead ballast and centreboard. Iroko / teak planking below the waterline, Togo Teak / Iroko above the waterline with seamsavers on interior. Iroko framing. Teak laid deck and coach roof.
boat.full_description: Tannhauser is a ketch rigged German racing cruiser built in the early 1960s to a 1959 design (according to the rigging plan, which is annotated in French). The designer and builder are currently unknown, but historic surveys state the hull was built in Ghana then shipped to Germany for fitting out, completed c.1963. Hull construction is exactly to Lloyds A1 standard for wood construction fastened with copper, and was built to exacting tolerances with very fine seams and seam savers on the inside seams (rebated into the iroko frames). The centreboard runs most of the length of the keel, and is an iroko blade with a stainless steel internal cover. The centreboard is raised an lowered by hand winch from the cockpit. Draft with centreboard down increases to 8 feet. The interior reflects the high standards of finish and attention to detail prevalent in German yards of the period. She has undergone several refits and refurbishments, including having the original engine replaced with a Bukh 36, which now occupies what would have been a small stern cabin, replacement of the teak deck in the 2000s, some hull replanking and main mast rebuilding in 2022. Currently in the final phases of renewing brightwork and detail repairs.
boat.name: Tannhauser
boat.place_built: Hull built in Ghana, fitted out in Germany
boat.short_description: German 1950s design racing cruiser built in the early 1960s
